messages.message: Quick question, our UDFs are still not capable of reading random resource files, correct? Because binarization will not package them up?
I think @dlluncor put in a fix for this. Not sure how to use it though

My understanding is that if you put your UDF under `.flow/ib/custom/...`, you can put resource files under that folder and when binarizing they will be packed up. See https://www.instabase.com/ib_solutions/solutions/fs/Instabase%20Drive/.flow/ib/custom/us_markets/get_name_dict_matching.py for an example, and https://www.instabase.com/ib_solutions/solutions/fs/Instabase%20Drive/pre-built/us-markets/demo-import-custom-udf/samples/scripts/imported_udf.py for how to use a UDF under `.flow/ib/custom/xxx`
oh so we still can’t access random files from the filesystem from like the output of previous steps?

what do you mean by “random files”? i don’t think a flow binary has access to the general file system beyond its output folder (so output of previous steps should be fine, but not a random file in the filestystem)
oh i just meant output of previous steps haha. so it does have access to that?
i think so, david can confirm :slightly_smiling_face:
This works even if it is not a python file?
If you mean if the resource file is not a python file - yes
Just a side note: in the custom UDF framework, your resource file will be packed into the binary (so your goal is not to have the resource file inside a binary at all, it’s not what you want)

Yes what Kerry mentioned here is correct. You can package up a resource file using the .flow/ib/custom method.

If you want to read an arbitrary file from the filesystem, you can use the ibfile handle. See the Special Refiner variable section in our documentation to see the interface for the ibfile handle
